Dick Harper.Action: Runs actively through many stages of life, engages in multiple activities like sports, delivering newspapers, and running for class office.
Works hard in aerospace and mathematical subjects to get good grades and a good job.
Engages in extracurricular activities like playing ball and trying out for a play, balancing work and leisure.
Obtains a fine job and is called an engineer at Dixon Aircraft.
Happily plays with family and pet, showing contentment but no professional action.
Stops short and notices a Mexican worker lazily painting out executive names, indicating awareness of layoffs.
Comments 'Christ, the body count is getting heavy around here' upon seeing layoffs and employee despair.
Appears perturbed by drunken Bob’s behavior, showing concern rather than dismissal.
Emerges from car assured and carrying a professional attache case, strides confidently toward building.
Stops short and surveys the parking lot noticing changes in reserved executive parking spots being painted over.
Passes through a largely empty office environment and reacts to disturbing signs of company decline with a terse comment.
Appears perturbed but does not take obvious action to address company crisis or morale issues.
Acknowledges the difficult times and agrees with Charlie's negative assessment without argument, showing understanding and camaraderie.
Brings a plan to reorganize his department and attempts to discuss it with Charlie, demonstrating responsibility and engagement.
Does not challenge Charlie's cynical and frustrated statements, instead joins in with brief affirmations, which could show either respect or lack of assertiveness.
Prepares a plan to reorganize his department and presents it to his superior.
Repeatedly agrees with Sanford's negative assessment without offering counterpoints or solutions.
Maintains composure and participates in conversation with a senior executive despite a pessimistic atmosphere.
Seems to lack confidence or assertiveness when his plan is interrupted and somewhat dismissed by Sanford.
Responds supportively and sincerely when Charlie says he can level with him and tell him anything.
Laughs uneasily at Charlie's joke about firing him, showing some discomfort but maintaining friendliness.
Expresses concern and disbelief when Charlie indicates he is serious about firing him, showing he cares about their relationship.
Questions the fairness of being fired despite good performance, indicating trust in his own merit and openness to dialogue.
Glares at Charlie who is feigning sleep when confessing distressing statements, then leaves without engaging further.
Responds politely and with thanks to Eleanor's sympathy about leaving the company.
Forgets company credit cards but intends to return them the next day rather than immediately.
Drives away angrily, muttering to himself after leaving the office.
Stands glaring at Charlie uncertainly, then simply gathers papers and leaves without confronting or resolving the issue.
Replies politely and briefly to Eleanor but forgets his credit cards in another suit, promising to bring them later.
Drives angrily, almost stripping the gears of his car, indicating loss of composure.
Offers to buy drinks for everyone at the bar, 'Drinks on the house,' and graciously acknowledges their toast.
Keeps good-natured and generous despite the bartender informing him his credit card is cancelled.
Offers to buy drinks for everyone at the bar, showing generosity and social confidence.
Attempts to pay the bill with a company credit card, but the card is cancelled, showing lack of foresight or oversight about his financial situation.
Seething but still digs into his pockets to pay the bartender despite frustration.
Smiles evilly, damages car deliberately and waves manically to small audience.
Ignores Mr. Goldoni who confronts him about pool payment.
Seething but still pays the bill promptly despite frustration.
Accidentally runs into concrete bumper guard while reversing his car.
Smiles maniaciously and waves triumphantly despite apparent car damage and confusion of onlookers.
Ignores the menacing contractor Goldoni when confronted about pool payment.
Shouts aggressively at Goldoni while arguing about payment, dismissing his wife's mention in a harsh manner.
Responds tensely to his son Billy's question with 'Not now, Billy,' showing impatience.
Admits to being fired openly to Jane and Goldoni, showing some honesty and openness.
Thrusts a statement demanding a check for the pool payment, showing assertiveness.
Shouts angrily that he has been fired and disregards his wife's input.
Attempts to handle confrontation with Goldoni but appears tense and intimidated.
Dismisses his son Billy's question about the car, showing poor emotional management during stress.
Tries stunts on Billy's skateboard to entertain or cheer up Jane and their child.
Maintains morose silence when Jane expresses anger about him being fired.
Whistles in amazement after hearing astrological bad news, showing surprise but no action to counter it.
Maintains a morose silence after being fired, displaying passivity rather than confidence or proactive behavior.
Parodies his unemployment situation to his son, trying to make light of sad circumstances and wrestles playfully with him.
Weary phone calls and silently crosses off last hope on job list, shows internal despair but remains earnest and sincere about difficulties.
Jokes about his son's lack of job to lighten mood, but the underlying context shows care and effort to protect his son from worry.
Silent, listless dinner with family, no conversation; possible emotional withdrawal or inability to connect in difficult times.
Responds to Jane's cheer with determination about finding a job, showing sincerity and openness.
Puts himself in a vulnerable position by posing nude as an art model, indicating openness and trustworthiness.
Attempts to apply for bartender job in a topless bar, showing adaptability but no clear indication of warmth.
Expresses melancholy and frustration about being unemployed despite having worked hard all his life.
Avoids prolonged interaction with Jane by leaving abruptly after a brief, affectionate moment.
Carries himself with a forlorn look and feels out of place among the unemployed, showing sensitivity to others' circumstances.
Responds honestly but briefly to the elderly woman's assumption, showing a degree of politeness despite discomfort.
Dresses formally for a difficult situation, attends unemployment office despite discomfort.
Shows sullen and forlorn attitude about unemployment and financial hardship.
Expresses overconfidence in a future job opportunity without taking immediate practical steps.
Walks among unemployed, attracting attention due to his appearance, suggesting some awareness of social cues.
Appears lost and panic-stricken inside the unemployment office.
Greets Raoul and shows polite recognition despite discomfort.
Is uncomfortable but accepts Raoul's help and advice.
Acknowledges Raoul and responds appropriately, showing social awareness and composure despite discomfort.
Is about to join the wrong line at the information desk, showing lack of initial understanding of the process.
Accepts help from Raoul who redirects him to the correct line, indicating willingness to receive assistance but some dependence on others.
Spends time socializing with Raoul and others at a bar, engaging in a friendly game of pool.
Spending time at a bar, casually playing pool with Raoul, showing no proactive effort or concern about his current difficulties.
Watches Raoul play pool with admiration, showing appreciation for others' skill.
Comes home to find his house darkened and his garden stripped due to repossession, reacts with stunned disbelief but no overt anger or blame.
Explains the loss of electricity to his son Billy as 'something of a misunderstanding' between them and the utility company, attempting to soften the situation for his child.
Admires Raoul's skill at pool but does not demonstrate any pool skill himself.
Walks slowly to the front door in stunned disbelief as his garden is repossessed and lights go out, showing shock and lack of immediate problem-solving.
Responds calmly to son Billy's question about the power outage, indicating knowledge of a 'misunderstanding' with the utility company.
No direct action taken to resolve the repossession or power outage during the excerpt.
Pours himself a small scotch, draining the bottle, suggesting stress and possible poor coping without addressing problems directly.
Attempts to reassure Jane that things aren't all that bad despite serious financial troubles, showing some confidence but perhaps unrealistic assessment.
Acknowledges financial strain but focuses on house ownership without addressing mortgage debt or lack of assets realistically.
Dismisses Jane's concerns about insurance and finances with a reckless confidence ('Dick Harper is in his prime'), showing denial rather than capability.
Demands clear information about his health directly from Jane, revealing assertiveness and desire for clarity.
Admits to gambling on investments and losing, insists he was not reckless but a victim of the economy.
Claims to be a faithful husband and denies suspicion about personal matters.
Appears defensive and somewhat evasive about financial decisions, avoiding full transparency.
Leans close to Jane and implores her for information, showing vulnerability and seeking connection.
Blames external economic forces and himself for losses, without taking full accountability for reckless behavior.
Insists that his financial decisions were sound and not gambles despite evidence to the contrary.
Fails to foresee or understand the risks of stock options, gold prices, and real estate investments collapsing.
Shows defensive and somewhat evasive behavior when questioned about financial failures.
Admits regret and implores Jane to tell him the truth, showing some awareness of problem but lacking proactive solutions.
Considers taking low-status jobs to support family despite pride.
Makes a sarcastic and dismissive remark questioning Jane's job qualifications, suggesting she might be a 'hooker'.
Laughs and slaps his knee in simulated delight.
Allows Jane to sit close to him at the tennis courts, showing some physical warmth.
Waited three months before applying for unemployment, delaying access to needed resources.
Considers taking low-skill jobs such as waiter or bus boy to support the family.
Expresses skepticism and makes sarcastic remarks about Jane's ability to get a job despite her qualifications.
Acknowledges the financial advantage of unemployment benefits over low-wage jobs and follows the plan to collect unemployment and apply for food stamps.
Enormously amused by Raymond's story, tries to suppress laughter but then openly mocks him with a derogatory comment.
Dismisses the clerk's correction about the transsexual person, insists on using offensive slang.
Tries to keep himself from laughing at Raymond's story, shows awareness of social situations but responds with amusement rather than empathy or discretion.
Approaches the unemployment clerk confidently to claim his unemployment benefits despite the discouraging circumstances.
Expresses doubt about his own status and competence by saying he is no longer an aerospace executive and that no one needs his skill set anymore.
Realizes that the clerk is gay after some consideration.
Initial ignorance or insensitivity in his choice of words and assumptions about the clerk.
Walks with Raoul through swap meet, chatting casually and lighting cigarettes together.
Questions the ethics of being a 'welfare chiseler' and expresses concern about potential consequences.
Shows eagerness and is pleased at the prospect of easy cash work despite ethical concerns.
Engages in honest dialogue about work and unemployment rules, shows willingness to understand different perspectives.
Apologizes to Raoul after being called a welfare chiseler.
Acknowledges rules about working and collecting unemployment, showing awareness of legal boundaries.
Expresses confusion or reconsideration about breaking rules after Raoul's argument, indicating openness but possible lack of firm judgment.
Accidentally yells and causes a set piece to wobble during a performance, letting audience laugh and possibly drawing negative attention.
Shares his concerns about unemployment and its impact on family income openly with Raoul.
Considers protecting Jane from harsh truths by debating whether to tell her about his unemployment.
Engages patiently and calmly with a loan officer who treats him with derision.
Engages with loan officer, attempts to negotiate and defend assets intelligently.
Expresses worry about long-term unemployment and financial impact calmly, seeks advice from friend.
Feels overwhelmed by circumstances but continues to pursue options for financial support.
Reveals financial difficulties openly but remains proactive during difficult conversation.
No clear plan shown for overcoming financial hardship beyond seeking loans.
Engages in the negotiation over a loan, stays calm and cooperative.
Responds quietly during the robbery without causing disturbance.
Attempts to clarify the source and legality of the money during the robbery, trying to negotiate calmly with the robber.
Shares or slides the money to another character (Ned) during the robbery, indicating trust or cooperation.
Clutches a large sum of money and tries to explain the situation calmly to the robber, attempting to negotiate and clarify ownership.
Slides the money to Ned indicating trust and presence of mind under stress.
Engages in a verbal exchange trying to reason about the money and interest.
Continues to speak up despite warnings from the robber, showing some confidence but also risking escalation.
Gets hit on the head by a robber, unable to prevent being overpowered and captured.
Responds calmly to police, checks on Jane's well-being after the robbery.
Puzzled when Ned suggests lying about losses to insurance for personal gain.
Laughs with Jane about the unexpected money, puts his arms around her to comfort her.
Mocks modestly about turning Jane in for the reward, engaging in playful banter.
Examines the unexpected money carefully and acknowledges its amount, showing awareness and calmness.
Laughs at Jane's distress over having committed a crime, possibly undermining seriousness of the situation.
Engages in a brief rational discussion with Jane about the impracticality of returning the money, demonstrating quick thinking and pragmatic understanding.
Responds with humor and playful banter to Jane’s worries and their financial problems, maintaining morale rather than addressing issues directly.
Celebrates with family, preparing a special dinner and dressed formally for a party.
Attempts to include and explain the situation to Mr. Johnson, though Johnson remains incredulous.
No visible hostility or rudeness toward the visiting official despite tense circumstances.
Enters the dining room carrying a roast beef on a carving board and manages to set it down without dropping it.
Attempts to explain or clarify a situation to Mr. Johnson, showing some initiative but seemingly failing to effectively handle the hostile visitor.
Rejects selling the house despite financial difficulties, insists on maintaining pride in what he worked hard for.
Tells Jane 'We'll make the payments. Don't worry.' to reassure her during financial stress.
Clumsily tries to hold a gun at a gun shop, indicating uncertainty and vulnerability.
Says 'Stick 'em up' to Jane in the bedroom, playfully using a gun, suggesting a mix of humor but possibly tension.
Insists on not selling the house despite financial difficulties, showing stubbornness and unwillingness to adapt.
Tries to stay optimistic and believe current financial problems are temporary and solvable.
Clumsily chooses and handles a gun without knowing how to properly use it.
Practices holding up a store with a gun, tries to speak clearly but looks ridiculous with pantyhose mask.
Angrily tells Jane not to sneak up on him with a gun, causing her to be startled.
Admits to being a loser and a washout, showing vulnerability.
Refuses Jane’s offer to join him in the hold-up initially.
Considers including their child Billy in the criminal act, despite Jane’s insistence.
Practices holding up with a gun but muffles his speech with a pantyhose mask, making himself incomprehensible.
Shows frustration and self-doubt, verbalizing that he is a wash-out and not capable.
Insists on doing the hold-up alone and initially refuses Jane's involvement.
Attempts to go through with a criminal act but lacks confidence and control, as indicated by his behavior and dialogue.
Allows Jane to come along on the risky plan after making her promise to obey him.
Shows impatience when Jane comments on where he puts the gun.
Uses humor and engages in playful banter with Jane about what to wear.
Demonstrates protectiveness and concern as he crouches defensively during a TV gun battle, suggesting sensitivity to danger.
Does not seem to reassure Jane fully about the crime plan beyond stating they won't shoot anyone.
Agrees that Jane can come only if she follows his instructions exactly, demonstrating control and leadership.
Initially chooses an overtly conspicuous outfit, showing poor judgment about discretion in a risky situation.
Changes into a more appropriate outfit after Jane’s suggestion, indicating adaptability and responsiveness.
Attempts to carry a hot coal as a gun by sticking it down his pants, showing a lack of practical problem-solving and awareness.
Decides to wear a jacket to better conceal the weapon, correcting his earlier mistake.
Claims he will not shoot anyone and tries to reassure Jane, demonstrating an understanding of the limits and goals of their plan.
Shows physical discomfort and appears tense when sitting in the car with gun awkwardly positioned, suggesting some nervousness or lack of ease.
Uses humor to defuse tension despite pain (Ho, ho. Very funny).
Commands Jane abruptly ('Just drive, damn it').
Quickly rearranges the gun pointed at him without panic.
Commands Jane to just drive and follow his instructions despite tense situation.
Responds sarcastically to Jane's comment about the gun.
Does not explain his plan clearly when questioned about how he intended to get to the crime scene if Jane hadn't come home.
